title: AB 2687
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. Blood alcohol concentration is measured in grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. In California, driving with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher is prohibited. It is based on grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. In prosecution, if a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood within three hours after driving, it is presumed they had the same amount at the time of driving. It is illegal for a drug addict to drive a vehicle in California, except for those in an approved narcotic treatment program. It is unlawful to drive a commercial motor vehicle with 0.04 percent or more of alcohol in the blood. A chemical test within three hours after driving can be used as evidence. It is illegal to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04 percent or more of alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is present. A passenger for hire is defined as someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. In a prosecution, it is assumed that the person had 0.04 percent or more alcohol in their blood while driving. In a prosecution, it is assumed that the person had 0.04 percent or more alcohol in their blood while driving, with a rebuttable presumption based on chemical test results within three hours. It is illegal to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs. Section 23153 of the Vehicle Code prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol, leading to bodily injury to others. It is unlawful to drive with 0.08 percent or more of alcohol in the blood and cause bodily injury to another person. There is a rebuttable presumption if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.08 percent or more of alcohol in the blood. In proving negligence in driving, it is not necessary to show a specific violation of the law. It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, leading to bodily injury to others. A chemical test within three hours can be used as evidence. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and causes bodily injury to someone else. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. In cases involving a "passenger for hire," it is presumed that the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if they had that level within three hours of a chemical test after driving. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to someone other than the driver. The act does not require reimbursement under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
